prompt_templates.title: AI-Assisted Agent Generation
prompt_templates.prompt:
Create an agent configuration based on this request: "[YOUR DESCRIPTION]"

Requirements:
1. Extract core intent and responsibilities
2. Design expert persona for the domain
3. Create comprehensive system prompt with clear behavioral boundaries, specific methodologies, edge case handling, and output format
4. Create identifier (lowercase, hyphens, 3-50 chars)
5. Write description with triggering conditions
6. Include 2-3 <example> blocks showing when to use

Return JSON with: {"identifier": "agent-name", "whenToUse": "Use this agent when... Examples: <example>...</example>", "systemPrompt": "You are..."}
prompt_templates.scenario: When you need to quickly generate a well-structured agent configuration from a high-level description

prompt_templates.title: Validate Agent Structure
prompt_templates.scenario: After creating or modifying an agent file to check for structural errors and missing fields

prompt_templates.title: Design Triggering Examples
prompt_templates.prompt:
Create triggering examples for [agent-name] that handles [task]. Include:
1. Explicit request example
2. Proactive triggering after code written
3. Implicit request based on user context

Format: <example>Context: [scenario]\nuser: "[request]"\nassistant: "[response]"\n<commentary>[why trigger]</commentary>\nassistant: "I'll use the [agent-name] agent..."</example>
prompt_templates.scenario: When defining when and how an agent should be triggered by Claude

best_practices: Use 'inherit' for model unless agent requires specific capabilities
Include 2-4 concrete triggering examples with varied phrasing
Write system prompts in second person (You are..., You will...)
Restrict tools to minimum needed (principle of least privilege)
Define clear output format expectations in system prompt
Use descriptive identifiers that indicate primary function (avoid generic terms)
Include both proactive and reactive triggering examples
Structure system prompts with responsibilities, process steps, quality standards, and edge cases
Keep system prompts under 10,000 characters for optimal performance
Choose distinct colors for different agents in the same plugin
anti_patterns: Using generic agent names like 'helper' or 'assistant'
Omitting triggering examples from the description field
Writing system prompts in first person instead of second person
Creating agents with vague responsibilities or undefined output formats
Granting all tools access when only a subset is needed
Writing overly long system prompts (>10,000 characters) with diminishing returns
Including only one type of triggering scenario (only explicit or only proactive)
Skipping validation after creating agent files
Using underscores or special characters in agent identifiers

faq.question: When should I create an agent vs a command?
faq.answer: Agents are for autonomous, multi-step tasks that run independently (code review, test generation, security analysis). Commands are for user-initiated actions triggered explicitly. If the task requires decision-making and multiple tool calls without user input, use an agent.

faq.question: How do I make my agent trigger proactively?
faq.answer: Include examples in the description field showing Claude triggering the agent after relevant work is completed (e.g., after writing code, trigger code-reviewer). Add commentary explaining why proactive triggering is appropriate in that context.

faq.question: What's the best model setting for most agents?
faq.answer: Use 'inherit' so the agent uses the same model as the parent process. Only specify 'sonnet', 'opus', or 'haiku' if your agent requires specific model capabilities or performance characteristics.

faq.question: How many triggering examples should I include?
faq.answer: Include 2-4 examples covering explicit requests, proactive triggering, and different phrasings. More than 6 makes the description too long. Focus on the most important triggering scenarios.

faq.question: Can I restrict which tools an agent can use?
faq.answer: Yes, use the 'tools' field in frontmatter with an array of tool names (e.g., ["Read", "Grep", "Glob"] for read-only analysis). If omitted, the agent has access to all tools. Apply principle of least privilege.

faq.question: How do I validate my agent file?
faq.answer: Run './scripts/validate-agent.sh agents/your-agent.md' to check for required fields, correct formats, name constraints, and system prompt structure. The script checks for errors and provides warnings for improvement.

permissions: File read/write access for agent creation
